Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Processing of L2-specific multi-word units and the impact on representation and generalization: an ERP study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In their 2017 report on America's languages, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences' Commission on Language Learning recommends "a national strategy to improve access to as many languages as possible for people of every region, ethnicity, and socioeconomic background...to value language education as a persistent national need similar to education in math or English, and to ensure that a useful level of proficiency is within every student's reach" https://www.amacad.org/content/publications/pubContent.aspx?d=22478). This dissertation is a step towards beginning to answer this call. Adult second language learners are often able to function at some level in a foreign language, but the influence of the native language during second language learning and use is known to negatively affect proficiency levels. Second language learners often experience the frustration of trying to remember a recently learned word in a second language, but only being able to retrieve the word in the native language. An important goal, then, is to learn to regulate interference from the native language to achieve higher proficiency in a second language. This project proposes to investigate how this might be possible.

The electrophysiological brain activity of English speakers who are learning Spanish will be measured during the learning of new word combinations, for example, "despertar dudas." This collocation literally translates as "awaken doubts" but is expressed in English with the phrase "raise doubts". Using a word combination like "despertar dudas" requires the suppression of the English translation equivalent "raise doubts". This research project will examine the brain activity associated with learning in conditions that require ignoring interference from the native language to examine whether they lead to better learning and generalization when learners are exposed to new input.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using a second language is now known to bring numerous communicative and cultural advantages, but also benefits at a cognitive level. For example, research in the last decade has found that bilingual individuals with Alzheimer’s tend to show the symptoms of the disease about four years later than comparable monolinguals; a delay in the onset of symptoms that no medication available to date can match. Our current understanding indicates that bilinguals have an increased “cognitive reserve”, due to the need to constantly regulate activation and interference between the two languages they speak.

The experience of language competition is familiar even to beginner learners who make their first attempts to speak another language (e.g., during high school). A common experience is that producing words that are known in the second language is perceived as difficult, because the equivalent words in the dominant language are most accessible. The ability to retrieve and produce the words in the second language is believed to require inhibiting competition from the first language. But acquiring the skill of “regulating” (i.e., inhibiting) the activation of the native language may require practice in the appropriate conditions. This project investigated how certain training conditions may allow learners to momentarily suppress their more proficient language, in order to accommodate the second language. The present study tested the counter-intuitive prediction that learning would be improved when second-language practice conditions induce interference from the native language, as a way to gain experience in this skill.

To test this idea, this project used electroencephalography to investigate the brain “event-related potentials” (ERPs) of native English speakers as they learned and processed conventional expressions (multiword units) in Spanish. To illustrate, while native English speakers find expressions such as “running a business” or “raising doubts” perfectly conventional, the literal equivalents in Spanish would literally translate as “carrying a business” (“llevar un negocio”) or “awakening doubts” (“despertar dudas”). These partial differences result in low rates of success for e.g., native English speakers who attempt to master such expressions to communicate fluently in a second language. Based on our hypothesis, we created practice conditions in which learners of Spanish experienced low or high interference as they selected among different choices. In a low-interference condition, learners should select the appropriate words when an “distractor” word was easy to discard as implausible; in a high-interference condition, a distractor option was appropriate based on the native language but not in Spanish (e.g., the Spanish equivalent of “run” would seem like an appropriate option to express “run a business”, but “carry” is correct for Spanish).

The results of the study supported our hypothesis. The brain data from ERPs revealed that training in conditions that induced interference from the native language resulted in the temporary inhibition of those words. The inhibition of the native language in brain data predicted success in the ability to remember and produce the second-language responses in a test. In contrast, when learners practiced in conditions of low-interference, brain activity was not correlated with language learning success. The findings showed that inhibition of the native language predicted successful use of the second language; and that adequate practice conditions may train the ability to regulate competition from the stronger native language. The results have implications for linguistic and psychological science, as well as for individuals in the broader population who may benefit from the cognitive consequences associated with bilingualism.
